board-talks/ambidexterity-seminar/twiste.title: Twisted Ambidexterity via Spivak Data
board-talks/ambidexterity-seminar/twiste.description:
These notes are for a 30~40 minute talk on twisted ambidexterity in terms of Spivak data as appearing in Section 3.1-3.3 of the paper Parametrised Poincare Duality and Equivariant Fixed Points Methods[1], which was given as part of an Ambidexterity seminar at UIUC in Fall 2025. In the paper Hilman, Kirstein, and Kremer us the theory of parameterized -categories to formulate and prove results about equivariant Poincare duality and its applications to fixed point methods. In the process of their work they provide a generalization of Bastiann Cnossen's theory of twisted ambidexterity[2] to the context of parameterized -categories which are not necessarily locally presentable using a description analogous to the data for classical Poincare duality theorems.Let's recall the classical Poincare duality picture:Classical Poincare Duality for a closed -manifold , there exists an infinite cyclic local coefficient system on and a class such that the cap product with induces, for every local coefficient system on , the isomorphisms Alternatively we can formulate the statement in terms of local systems of spectra. Let be the unique map to a point, where we view as a space, forgetting its geometric structure. Then we get adjunctions
For a local system , we view (resp. ) as the homology (resp. cohomology) of with coefficients in the local system . This becomes precise once we take homotopy groups if is a constant local system at a spectrum. For example, the Spivak normal fibration of a smooth manifold allows us to construct a -invertible local system . The stable Pointryagin-Thom collapse map then can be viewed as a map , which from our perspective that represents represents the fundamental class for . We will describe later how we can form a cap product with the fundamental class as a morphism in :and Poincare duality can be interpreted as the requirement that this transformation is an equivalence. This can be seen to be a reformulation of twisted ambidexterity, where is the dualizing sheaf of . More generally, this can be done for any compact space . We say a space is a Poincare space if it has a dualizing sheaf that takes values in invertible spectra . Consequently, all closed manifolds are Poincare spaces.Before defining the general theory let's motivate through classical Poincare duality.Classical Poincare Duality For a closed smooth manifold , an embedding gives rise to a collapse map where is the normal bundle of the embedding. The stable homotopy type of this map doesn't depend on the choice of embedding, so we obtain a well-defined class , where the isomorphism is the Thom isomorphism and denotes the orientation local system for . Classical Poincare duality says that is an isomorphism. This motivates the definition of Spivak data. Throughout we fix an -topos which we work internal to. For an object , we write for the associated map to the terminal object.Spivak Datum Let and a symmetric monoidal -category which admits -shaped colimits. A -Spivak datum for consists of (i) an object , called the dualizing sheaf; (ii) a map in called the fundamental class (or collapse map). Capping Map Let be a symmetric monoidal -category which admits -shaped limits and colimits and satisfies the -projection formula (i.e. the Beck-Chevalley transformation is an equivalence for all ). For each -Spivak datum on we can construct a natural transformation which is a morphism in . Fundamental Class from a Capping Map Given a natural transformation , and writing for the adjunction unit, we obtain a collapse map as the composite where in the last equivalence we are using the projection formula. Collapse map for Capping Map There is an equivalence . Proof. Consider the commutative diagram
Then the top composite is precisely while the bottom composite is equivalent to by the triangle identity. ***We will see that the capping maps produced from Spivak data often intertwine the left and right Beck-Chevalley transformations. Module Pushforwards from Multiplicative Basechanges Suppose we have: Symmetric monoidal -categories , , A symmetric monoidal parameterized colimit-preserving functor as well as a -linear functor using the -linear structure on coming from , A map in and admit left Kan extensions along . Then for a -Spivak datum for , we define as the associated -Spivak datum for . The data also gives symmetric monoidal functors and , from which we can upgrade the functors , to - and a -linear one, respectively. The main examples of this structure that will be important is: (i) When and the -linear structure is given by the symmetric monoidality structure (ii) When , , and for some fixed object , so that the -linear structure on is the tautological one given by coming from the symmetric monoidal structure on . Throughout let be a symmetric monoidal -category which admits -shaped limits and colimits and satisfies the -projection formula (for example this holds when is a presentably symmetric monoidal -category).Twisted Ambidexterity A -Spivak datum on is twisted ambidextrous if the capping transformation is an equivalence. Note that we also have a relative version of this definition, where for an object we can use the basechange adjunction .Twisted Ambidextrous Map Consider a map in and a symmetric monoidal -category such that the -category admits shaped limits and colimits that satisfy the -projection formula. A -Spivak datum for is a -Spivak datum for . We say that such a Spivak datum exhibits as a -twisted ambidextrous map if it exhibits as a -twisted ambidextrous object.
We now show that in the presentable case twisted ambidextrous Spivak data are unique and that the notion of twisted ambidexterity is equivalent to that in[2-1].Twisted Ambidextrous Spivak Datum giving Adjunction Let be a twisted ambidextrous -Spivak datum for . The adjunction induces an adjunction whose unit is given by Proof.
The fact that the equivalence induces an adjunction follows from the uniqueness of adjoints (c.f. properties of adjunctions in infinity categoriesproperties of adjunctions in infinity categories). For the description of the adjunction unit, observe that we have the commuting diagram
where the bottom composite is the capping equivalence (pre-composed with ) and the right triangle is by the triangle identity. Thus, the claimed map is compatible with the unit under the capping equivalence , as desired. ***
Note that if and if is an internal left adjoint in , then its right adjoint must be of the form for a unique [2-2].The Presentable Case for Twisted Ambidexterity Let be a presentably symmetric monoidal -category and . (1) If is an internal left adjoint in with right adjoint , then the unit map forms a -twisted ambidextrous Spivak datum for . (2) If is a -twisted ambidextrous Spivak datum for , then the map is the unit map of a -linear adjunction In particular, if and are twisted ambidextrous Spivak data, then there is an equivalence so that the composite is equivalent to .
Combining this result with Proposition 3.8 in[2-3] we see that is -twisted ambidextrous in the current sense if and only if it is in Bastiann Cnossen's sense, and in this case the twisted norm map is an equivalence with inverse the map .Twisted Ambidextrous Objects in Presentable Case Let be a presentably symmetric monoidal -category. An object of is called -twisted ambidextrous if it admits a (necessarily unique) twisted ambidextrous Spivak datum with coefficients in . For a twisted -ambidextrous object , its associated Spivak datum is .The notion of Poincare duality comes from a special case of twisted ambidexterity where the local system for the Spivak datum takes values in tensor invertible objects.Poincare Spivak Datum A Spivak datum for with coefficients in is Poincare if it is twisted ambidextrous and takes values in . In the case that is presentably symmetric monoidal, we say that the object itself is -Poincare if it is twisted -ambidextrous and the unique twisted ambidextrous Spivak datum is Poincare.Again we can also define the relative version:Poincare Duality Maps Consider a map in and a symmetric monoidal -category such that the -category admits -shaped limits and colimits and satisfies the -projection formula. We say that a -Spivak datum for exhibits as a -Poincare duality map if it exhibits as a -Poincare duality object. Poincare Duality from Higher Semiadditivity (1) For any topos and any symmetric monoidal -category , the terminal object has the tautological Poincare -Spivak datum . (2) If is pointed, then the map in is -Poincare (3) If is semiadditive, then any finite fold map is -Poincare
(4) More generally, Poincare spaces with trivial dualizing sheaf come from the theory of higher semiadditivity (c.f. Introduction to SemiadditivityIntroduction to Semiadditivity and[3]) One of the important applications of the Spivak datum perspective is that it allows us to define a notion of degree for maps between Poincare spaces, which becomes an important computational invariant.Motivation: Classical Degree Recall that given a map between closed connected manifolds of the same dimension, we can assign to it a degree if is compatible with the orientation behaviour of and . Namely, given an identification of orientation local systems, the degree is given by the image of under . In order to generalize this to our current setting we'll need versions of (co)homological functoriality:(Co)homological Functoriality Consider a map in and a -category which admits - and -shaped (co)limits. We obtain transformations of functors coming from the left and right Beck-Chevalley transformations, respectively, associated to the commuting triangle . We call the homological functoriality map and the cohomological functoriality map. Degree of a map Consider a map in and a symmetric -category which admits - and -shaped (co)limits and satisfies the - and -projection formula. Suppose we have Spivak data for and for . A -degree datum for is an equivalence in . We define the -degree of as the point given by the composite We say that an equivalence exhibits as a map of -degree one. Commutative Monoid of Degrees If the Spivak datum is -twisted ambidextrous, then the equivalence endows with the structure of a commutative algebra in . This gives the structure of a commutative monoid in with unit . with Presentably Symmetric Monoidal Coefficients Let be a map of connected Poincare spaces of the same formal dimension . We consider situations when a degree datum exists for the map with the Poincare Spivak data and for , resp. . (1) , a degree datum exists uniquely since has contractible components. (2) For , writing for the first Stiefel-Whitney class of a space, a degree datum exists if and only if . On homotopy groups the composite then identifies with where and denote the orientation local systems. The degree is then given by , and agrees with the classical definition of the degree. (3) In surgery theory, one is often provided with a normal map so that we have homotopy equivalences and

reading-notes/homotopy-theory/k-theory/v.description:
In this note we investigate and introduce important geometric tools for studying vector bundles on manifolds, including connections, orientations, the Poincaré-Hopf Theorem, Holonomy, and their relation with cohomology classes. These notes primarily follow lectures by Rui Fernandes in the Spring of 2025 at UIUC.To begin we recall, and internalize, the classification of vector bundles via cocycles. Recall that for a topological space with an open cover and a topological group, a -valued cocycle is a family of continuous (smooth) maps such that for all and for all for all Note that given the first two conditions, the cocycle condition is equivalent to a functoriality condition, namely that . Two such cocycles on the same cover are said to be equivalent if we have a family of continuous (smooth) maps such thatMore generally we say two cocycles on are equivalent if there is some common refinement of their covers on which they are equivalent. reading-notes/homotopy-theory/k-theory/v.description:
In this note we aim to provide a more formal introduction to the theory of vector bundles on smooth manifolds following Chapter 10 in Lee's Smooth Manifolds[1]. This work generalizes the theory of the tangent bundle on manifolds.Consider a topological space throughout.Vector Bundle A real vector bundle of rank over is a topological space together with a surjective continuous map satisfying the following conditions: For each , the fiber over is endowed with the structure of a -dimensional vector space. For each , there exists a neighborhood of in and a homeomorphism , called a local trivialization of over , satisfying (i.e. is a bundle map over ) For each , the restriction is an isomorphism of vector spaces. The space is called the total space of the bundle, is called its base, and is its projection.
Note that a real vector bundle is precisely a locally trivial fibration (c.f. Basics of Fiber Bundles and Principal BundlesBasics of Fiber Bundles and Principal Bundles) with fiber , and with a choice of atlas such that the transition functions are linear isomorphisms on the fibers.If and are smooth manifolds with or without boundary, is a smooth map, and the local trivializations can be chosen to be diffeomorphisms, then is called a smooth vector bundle and any local trivialization that is a diffeomorphism is called a smooth local trivialization.We usually refer to rank-1 vector bundles as (real) line bundles. If we replace with above, and require all vector spaces to be -vector spaces, we obtain the notion of a complex vector bundle. In this note we will restrict to considering real vector bundles.Smooth Vector Bundle Maps are Submersions Suppose is a smooth vector bundle. Then is a surjective smooth submersion. Proof. reading-notes/homotopy-theory/k-theory/v.title: Orientations and the Thom Isomorphism
reading-notes/homotopy-theory/k-theory/v.description:
In this note we provide an introduction the Thom isomorphism and some of its important consequences following the work of Milnor and Stasheff in their book on Characteristic Classes[1]. We begin with a discussion on oriented bundles before surveying the Thom isomorphism, Euler classes, Thom spaces, and Stiefel-Whitney classes.Notation: Throughout we write for the Eilenberg-MacLane spectrum of a ring (or more generally abelian group) . If is a vector bundle, we write for the corresponding total space.To motivate our definition of an orientation for a vector bundle let's begin with a single vector space.Orientation on a vector space Let be a real vector space of dimension . An orientation of is an equivalence class of bases, where two (ordered) bases and are equivalent if and only if their change of basis matrix has positive determinant. Every vector space has two distinct orientations. We often equip with its canonical orientation given by the equivalence class containing the standard ordered basis .
Previously we've discussed orientations in the context of simplices when defining simplicial and singular homology in Basics of Homology - Simplicial and Singular HomologyBasics of Homology - Simplicial and Singular Homology. To see how these are related, let be an -simplex which is linearly embedded in the -dimensional vector space with ordered vertices . Then forms a basis on corresponding to an orientation of the vector space.We can interpret a choice of orientation for as a choice of one of the two possible generators for the singular homology groups To see this let denote the standard -simplex with canonically ordered vertices. Choose some orientation preserving linear embedding which maps the barycenter of to the zero vector, and hence the boundary of into . Then is a singular -simplex representing an element in the group of relative -cycles . The homology class of this -cycle is now the preferred generator for the homology group .Similarly, using dual bases we obtain a preferred generator of the cohomology group . We could also use a LES argument as in the following:Relative Cohomology of For a ring , and dually for homology. Proof. Note that deformation retracts to via ,
where the second isomorphism is from the isomorphism for along with the UCTthe UCT. On the other hand, since is contractible, while for . Thus, the statement follows from the LES of pairs. ***Note that explicitly the factor of comes in the LES from the associated SESThus, when , an orientation corresponds to choosing an orientation on either with an outward or inward normal.Let's now generalize to a vector bundle of fiber dimension , and give a first naive definition of orientation.Orientation on a Vector Bundle #1 An orientation for is a function assigning an orientation to each fiber of subject to the following local compatibility: For every , there exists a local trivialization with and such that for each fiber over , the homomorphism is orientation preserving. In terms of cohomology this says that to each fiber there is assigned a preferred generator The local compatibility condition implies that for each point in the base space, there exists a neighborhood and a cohomology class so that for each fiber over , the restriction In particular, these glue to give a Thom class . Moving forward we will write for without the zero section.Alternatively, recall that if is a vector bundle over of rank , we have its exterior power which is a line bundle over . Then a compatible choice of orientations is equivalent to a compatible choice of non-zero elements in the fibers for . Thus, is orientable in the above sense if and only if admits a non-vanishing section, and hence is a trivial line bundle. In this case, any two non-vanishing sections are said to be equivalent if there exists , , such that ( can be chosen to be smooth if and are). This gives a second definition for orientations:Orientation on a Vector Bundle #2 An orientation for is an equivalence class of non-vanishing sections . When , for a smooth manifold, this recovers the usual orientation of manifolds.
Using our cocycle classification of bundlescocycle classification of bundles, a vector bundle being orientable can be equivalently phrased as asking for the existence of a cocycle taking values in . This is the first case of a more general pattern of lifting the cocycle group for a bundle to give it additional structure.Orientation via Cocycles Let be a vector bundle of rank on a space admitting partitions of unity (e.g. paracompact Hausdorff). Then admits a non-vanishing section if and only if admits a description in terms of cocycles taking values in . Proof. First, suppose is orientable so we have a global non-vanishing section . Say that a local frame is positively oriented if for all , for . All local frames are either positively or negatively oriented, and multiplying by in one of the coordinates we can always replace a negatively oriented local frame by a positively oriented local frame. Then we obtain our desired cover by positive local trivializations.Conversely, if such local trivializations with cocycles exist, then we can define by taking a partition of unity and summing the induced orientations on the . *** Another example of this phenomena occurs with Riemannian metrics, where admits a Riemannian metric if and only if it admits a cocycle with values in the orthogonal group . Over paracompact spaces this always holds via a partition of unity argument. Alternatively, it can be shown that , the polar decomposition, where are the positive definite symmetric matrices contractible?.Warning A vector bundle over a manifold can be orientable without or being orientable. 2-3 property for orientability Let be a rank vector bundle over . Then if two of are orientable, then so is the third. Proof.
Step 1: Suppose is a short exact sequence of vector bundles over with constant rank maps, where , , and . We start by proving that the 2-of-3 property holds for short exact sequences. From our construction of local trivializations in Operations on Vector Bundles > ^7ff753Operations on Vector Bundles > ^7ff753 we can find a cover of with trivialization on that extends to a trivialization of , such that gives trivializations for , so that if are the cocycles for and are the cocycles for , then are cocycles for . Then the result follows since .Step 2: Consider the zero section . Then we have a diagram
so that is an epimorphism of vector bundles. Then we have a short exact sequence of vector bundles over . Note that since is an embedded submanifold for all , and is a linear subspace, for all , and these assemble to give a bundle map
where is given by the identity for the second factor and the composite for the first, so that we get a unique map of bundles over . It follows by rank considerations that , so we get a short exact sequence of vector bundles over .Step 3: is orientable if and only if is orientable combined with the short exact sequence in step 2 and the 2-of-3 property in step 1 now implies the result. The forward implication is clear since , so it suffices to assume is orientable. However, this will follow from the homotopy invariance of pullbacks of vector bundles, proved below, and the fact that deformation retracts onto under the zero section, so that we have a pullback composite diagram
*** ToDo: Show how this notion of orientation is equivalent to the cohomology one We now restrict to the cohomological description of orientations.Matrix Acting on Cohomology For , is given by multiplication by . Proof.

Before stating our generalized definition orientations, let's recall the notion of Thom Space from Topological Basics of SpectraTopological Basics of Spectra:Thom Space The Thom space of the rank vector bundle , denoted , is given by taking the one-point compactification of the fibers to give a sphere bundle whose fibers are homeomorphic to , and then collapsing the subspace containing all the newly created points at to a single point. In other words, Intuition: is just the vector bundle with a single additional point that can be reached by going to along any of the fibers of .Lemma: Alternate Description of Thom Space There is a homeomorphism , where is the unit disc bundle and is the unit sphere bundle, for any fixed choice of Riemannian metric on . Proof.
Fix a Riemannian metric on (this is always possible when the base space admits numerable covers, e.g. paracompact Hausdorff spaces, which all CW complexes are, c.f. existence of Riemannian metricsexistence of Riemannian metrics). For each , we have a natural map given by for , and for . These maps are continuous, and assemble into a bundle morphism , which in a local Riemannian chart is given by where is the quotient map followed by the natural isomorphism . Composing with the quotient to the Thom space we obtain a map of bundles which induces a homeomorphism , as desired. *** When is the trivial bundle, the Thom space is so when is non-trivial we can think of the Thom space as a twisted suspension of .Thom Space of Exterior Sum If and are vector bundles of constant finite rank, then we have a homeomorphism where the basepoint is given by the unique point at . Proof. Note that where we use to denote the one-point compactification. In particular, we see that , as desired. *** Thom Space of Whitney Sum with Trivial Bundle If is a finite rank vector bundle and is the rank trivial bundle over , then Proof. Note that where . Then we define the Thom spectrum of as the desuspended suspension spectrum
We also write for this spectrum. If is another presentation of the virtual bundle, then , so that by the computation for the Thom space of a Whitney Sumthe computation for the Thom space of a Whitney Sum, for , so that the spectra are stably equivalent. Thus, is well-defined up to stable equivalence of spectra.If is a closed manifold with tangent bundle , the virtual bundle , where is the normal bundle of some embedding . Thus, its Thom spectrum is stably equivalent to Since and are always cofibrations, instead of working with relative cohomology we can work with absolute cohomology, where This allows us to generalize orientations to multiplicative cohomology theories (c.f. )Cohomology Orientation on a Vector Bundle Let be a multiplicative cohomology theory and let be a vector bundle of rank . Then an -orientation or -Thom class on is an element of degree , in the reduced -cohomology ring of the Thom space of such that for every point , its restriction along is a generator in the sense that it is of the form for a unit in the ring and the image of the multiplicative unit under the suspension isomorphism . In other words, is a generator of as a -module.
ToDo: Add orientation material from[2] We'll begin by focusing on the case when is the cohomology theory induced by a ring . In this case the definition of orientation reduces to the following:-orientation An -orientation (or -Thom class) on is such that generates for all . Note that if is an -Thom class and , then is still an -Thom class.-Thom Classes are Universal If is a -Thom class and is the canonical change of rings map given by post-composing a cocycle by the unique ring map , then is an -Thom class. Proof. Note that for all , we have a commuting diagram
But ring maps send units, and hence generators, to generators, so if maps to a generator , then maps to a generator . ***As the proof shows, we have more generally that if admits an -orientation, and if we have a unital ring map , then also admits an -orientation given by change of rings in cohomology.Isomorphism of Relative Cohomology The inclusion induces an isomorphism on cohomology rings Proof. But and are deformation retracts, and hence induce isomorphisms on cohomology, so that by the 5-lemma we have the desired isomorphism on relative cohomology. ***Example Note that , so . Thus, there is no -Thom class, and hence no -Thom class, so is not -orientable. Note: For the remainder of this subsection, unless stated otherwise, we will be using -coefficients, and notate it by . Thom Isomorphism for Trivial Bundle If is trivial, then where going right to left for . In particular, If and , then so is a Thom class if and only if each , if and only if is a unit in . For example, if there is a unique Thom class, and if there are Thom classes. If is a Thom class then the map is an isomorphism, since is a unit. This last observation generalizes to the Thom isomorphism. Before proving this generalization we'll need some preliminaries. Pulling Back Thom Classes Suppose is a vector bundle, , and a Thom class. Then is a Thom class, where is the induced map on total spaces. Proof. Note that yields an isomorphism on fibers. We will begin our discussion of the Thom isomorphism theorem in the simplifying context where our coefficient ring is the field . Since we are in field coefficients the Kunneth FormulaKunneth Formula applies. Thus, for any base space we have a cohomology isomorphism

This is also done in the example for thom isomorphisms of trivial bundlesthe example for thom isomorphisms of trivial bundles.Thom Isomorphism for Trivial Bundle For any topological space , any , and any ring , the map on cohomology is an isomorphism The general claim of Thom's isomorphism theorem is as follows:Theorem: Thom Isomorphism Theorem for -coefficients Let be an -plane bundle with projection . Then there is a unique cohomology class whose restriction to is non-zero for every fiber . Furthermore, the map is an isomorphism. Note that taking implies that for .Proof. Before treating the general case we need some preliminary results. First, if is oriented, as defined in definition 1definition 1, then for each fiber we have a preferred choice of generator . In this note we aim to provide a basic introduction to the theory of fiber bundles, and the special role principal bundles play in their classification. These notes are primarily adapted from Rui's Math 519 course notes in Spring 2025 at UIUC, with additional perspectives from Jake Rasmussen's Math 526 in Fall 2024.To begin we'll start with the theory of fiber bundles and locally trivial fibrations. Throughout let denote the ambient category of topological objects (e.g. topological spaces, compactly generated weak Hausdorff spaces, possibly infinite dimensional smooth manifolds, etc.).Locally Trivial Fibration A locally trivial fibration with fiber type is a map such that for every , there exists an open neighborhood of of and an isomorphism in . Note that if is a trivializing cover for a fiber bundle with fiber type , then the transition function determines a cocycle (which is a map in if it is a cartesian closed category, which we assume moving forward).If in addition is a group object such that we have an effective group action (i.e. the induced map is a monomorphism), then we can add the requirement that the cocycle takes values in the image of . This leads to the notion of fiber bundle.Fiber Bundle A fiber bundle with fiber and structure group consists of a locally trivial fibration with fiber type , an effective left -action , and a collection of locally trivializing charts such that There exists in , such that The collection is maximal in the sense that if is a trivializing chart such that there exists with , then . When is a vector space and , this definition recovers the notion of a vector bundle. When , with the free transitive action by left translation, this definition encodes the notion of a -principal bundle. A morphism of -fiber bundles is a map in such that for all , the induced map given by pulling back along fibers is a map of -spaces. In particular, if and are trivializations for and , with , then being -equivariant implies that for each , the induced map must satisfy , so that we get an induced map such that .Now, we say that -cocycles and for covers of are equivalent if there exists a common refinement for the open covers together with maps such that for all , If denotes the set of equivalence classes of -cocycles, then we have a one-to-one correspondence between elements of and isomorphism classes of -fiber bundles over with fiber fixed. Explicitly, given a -cocycle for a cover of , the associated -fiber bundle is Construction: Reduction of Structure Group Given a closed subgroup , we say that the structure group of a -fiber bundle can be reduced to if there exists a cocycle for with values in . Reduction Examples A -fiber bundle is trivial (i.e. isomorphic to ) if and only if the structure group can be reduced to . For a vector bundle, the structure group can be reduced to if and only if it is orientable if and only if it admits a metric if and only if it is orientable and admits a metric Notice that the cocycle description does not reference the fiber . As a consequence of the previous correspondence, we then have the following: To every -fiber bundle with fiber , there is associated a -principal bundle (defined up to isomorphism) Alternatively, to every -principal bundle, , if is a space with effective -action , we have an associated -fiber bundle with fiber . Further, and is a -cocycle associated to the -principal bundle , so that , thenso that corresponds to the same cocycle as .Theorem: Fiber Bundles Via Principal Bundles Via Cocycles Let be agroup, let be a space with an effective -action, and let . Then the composite of bijections can be given explicitly by sending a -principal bundle to the -fiber bundle . This perspective plays an essential role due to the simplicity with which -Principal bundles can be described, and the number of classifying space results associated with them.First, let's recall some constructions of -principal bundles when is or .Theorem: Slice Theorem Let be a proper action. For each there exists an embedded submanifold containing and satisfying is -invariant , where is the orbit at in For and such that , . Proof. TBL *** Theorem: Smooth Structure on Quotient If is a free and proper action, then the quotient space has a unique (smooth) structure such that the quotient map is a submersion. Proof. TBL *** Theorem: Quotient Principal Bundle Let be a free and proper right action. Then is a -principal bundle. Further, every -principal bundle is of this form. Proof. TBL *** Thus, we can identify -principal bundles with free and proper right actions , so that for any left action , we get another free and proper action , where , so that quotienting by this action gives the associated bundle .Associated Bundles The trivial -principal bundle is , with associated bundle for any action the trivial -bundle . Homogeneous spaces: For a closed subgroup, is a principal -bundle Covering Spaces: A universal covering is a principal -bundle . More generally, if is a normal subgroup, is a covering space with group of deck transformations , which is a principal -bundle. Frame Bundle For any vector bundle with fiber a vector space , it's associated frame bundle is the principal -bundle The associated bundle is . In particular, a -principal bundle has a section if and only if we have a -equivariant map in the sense that .In the case where is a -fiber bundle with -contractible, we always have sections, and any two sections are homotopic. Indeed, if is -contractible, so that we have a -equivariant homotopy for , where is necessarily a -fixed point, then gives a -equivariant map, and hence a section, while any other -equivariant map is -homotopic to this one, and hence induces homotopic sections.-Structure for a Manifold Given a closed subgroup and a (smooth) manifold , a reduction of is called a -structure. The reduction is called integrable if it locally has sections consisting of commuting vector fields (equivalently if has local charts with induced local frames determining local sections of the reduced -Principal bundle ). board-talks/ambidexterity-seminar/applic.title: Applications and Examples in Equivariant Poincare Duality
board-talks/ambidexterity-seminar/applic.description:
These notes are for a 30~40 minute talk on applications and examples of twisted ambidexerity in equivariant Poincare duality in Sections 4.1-4.4 of the paper Parametrised Poincare Duality and Equivariant Fixed Points Methods[1], which was given as part of an Ambidexterity seminar at UIUC in Fall 2025. Let's begin by recalling some preliminary notions and notations in the parameterized formulation of equivariant homotopy theory. Throughout will be a fixed compact Lie group. We write for the category of -spaces where is the full subcategory of spanned by the orbits for a closed subgroup. We write for the -category of -categories. For a -category , we write its value at an orbit by .Standard Facts about Orbit Category For any morphism of compact Lie groups, there is an induction functor sending an -orbit to , which will be a -orbit. If is an epimorphism, we obtain a fully faithful right adjoint given by restriction: These can be constructed on the level of topologically enriched categories. For a closed subgroup , induction induces an equivalence of topologically enriched categories whose inverse sends to the homogeneous -space given as the fiber over , . For a continuous homomorphism of compact Lie groups we obtain two adjunctions
called induction, restriction, and coinduction, where is given by restriction along , and while . When is an epimorphism (for closed normal subgroup), admits a further right adjoint, which is written as (coinflation) given by right Kan extension along the fully-faithful right adjoint to . In particular, and are fully-faithful in this case, and . Thus, we obtain the diagram of adjunctions:
Here the maps , , , and are called the genuine quotient, inflation, genuine fixed points, and coinflation, respectively. We often also write and as and , respectively.Note that for a orbit , its induction to is given by the double cosetsince is normal. From the left Kan extension formula defining the genuine quotient, we obtainIn order to work with stability in the parameterized context, the naive definition of stably valued -categories is insufficient. Fibrewise Pointed (resp. info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.
